report_title: Gym, Health & Fitness Clubs in the US
executive_summary: The Gym, Health and Fitness Clubs industry suffered from fluctuations in the broader economy's stability despite growth in health consciousness over the past few years. These clubs are riding a wave of change, adapting swiftly to economic pressures and fluctuating consumer preferences.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Flexible Membership Models Rise Because of Economic Pressure
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The largest consumer demographic, aged 20 to 64, has stagnated, shrinking the potential gym-goer market. Many in this age group are new to the workforce or have low disposable income, which limits their ability to afford membership fees and ancillary services. Inflation has exacerbated financial pressures on both consumers and gym owners. Rising costs for utilities, rent, and wages have led to higher membership fees, hurting demand from budget-conscious clientele.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Gyms, Health and Fitness Clubs Adapt to Changing Fitness Trends
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Indicating high participation. Financial constraints are prevalent, but interest in health and fitness remains strong. In response to economic pressures, many gyms have adapted by offering more flexible membership options. Transitioning from traditional, hard-to-cancel memberships to month-to-month or pay-as-you-go plans aligns with consumer preferences for affordability and convenience.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Technological Advancements Enhance Users' Fitness Journey
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: As more people transition to at-home and online workouts, the advent of wearable health trackers has simplified monitoring progress at the gym. This trend underscores the growing role of technology in fitness. Health, diet and fitness monitoring apps have gained popularity, making it easier for consumers to stay committed to their fitness journeys.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Consumers enjoy working out at home
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The prevalence of online fitness classes and the increased purchase of at-home gym equipment are reshaping consumer workout habits, presenting significant challenges for traditional gyms and fitness clubs. Although gyms maintain an advantage with access to various equipment, more consumers are investing in exercise gear for their homes.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Exercise Plays a Big Role in Recovery and Rehabilitation
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Exercise is no longer viewed solely as a means to achieve physical fitness but as a vital component endorsed by medical professionals for wellness and recovery. Regular exercise is linked to a lower resting heart and respiratory rate and strengthens the parasympathetic nervous system, responsible for relaxation, digestion and recovery.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: An Aging Population Will Join Gyms and Fitness Clubs
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As the baby boomer population grows, the gym, health and fitness club sector in the US will benefit significantly. Baby boomers are one of the most reliable and consistent consumer groups, making them a lucrative market.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: A Substantial Emphasis on Health and Well-Being
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: By prioritizing fitness and wellness, individuals aim to avoid the financial burden of medical treatments, driving growth in gym and fitness center memberships and health club participation.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: An Evolving Industry Landscape Will Create More Competition
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: A continuing trend from the last few years has been a drop in market concentration. The expansion of smaller gyms and fitness centers that are more localized and personalized is set to continue, with boutique fitness clubs being particularly trendy with younger demographics.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Continued Adoption of Technology Will Enhance Experience
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As consumers' time spent on leisure and sports is set to inch upward, many gym goers will seek to maximize their use of technology to preserve their limited free time.

industry_definition: Gyms and health and fitness clubs feature exercise machines and other active physical fitness conditioning or recreational sports activities, like swimming, skating or racquet sports. Gyms and health clubs also facilitate fitness instruction.

threats: Time spent on leisure and sports

key_trends: The constant demand to stay healthy and active plays an integral role in establishing a competitive marketplace for industry clubs.

Economic stability is a key point of emphasis. The capture of a significant amount of the market is highly intertwined with how well the economy is doing and whether consumers have the fiscal flexibility to afford a gym membership.

Home workouts are on the rise, but not for everyone. While online classes and home gym equipment are gaining popularity, the high costs of advanced at-home systems like Peloton deter many from making the switch.

Tech is changing how we work out. Wearable health trackers and fitness apps are becoming essential tools for gym-goers and trainers alike, making it easier to monitor progress and customize workout plans.

market_segmentation.segment_description: This market segment captures the number of people younger than 18 participating in physical activities by going to the gym. Since most teenagers are not financially independent, the success of this segment is impacted by a parent or guardian's financial situation.
This market segment comprises consumers between 18 and 34 who participate in fitness centers and go to the gym. The resiliency of this market segment is dependent on consumer confidence.

Consumers between ages 35 and 50 are the most difficult to consistently secure as a consumer base, thanks to their dueling responsibilities between work and home care, which makes time even more valuable.

One of the most important and highly sought-after age groups, consumers over the age of 50 make up a considerable chunk of the overall markets, with the industry catering significant resources and changes to help secure this age group.

products_and_services.product_description: This product segment consists of charges levied on gym or fitness center subscriptions. The main goal of membership fees is to produce cash flows that cover the cost of amenities at the fitness center.

This product segment consists of revenue generated via personal trainers. Typically, the goal of personal trainers is to conduct classes or workouts with individual consumers or small groups of people who want to experience results quickly.
Guest admissions include revenue generated from the presence or arrival of guests into gyms and fitness centers.

The meals and beverages product segment consists of revenue generated from the sales of food and beverages at gym, health and fitness centers. Since consumers travel to work out and will exert a lot of energy during their training, there's a constant demand for the gym to maintain a constant supply of beverages and snacks that can satisfy consumers' demands.

The merchandise sales product segment includes revenue generated from the sales of merchandise or other gear at gyms and fitness centers. This segment faced a slight drop, particularly as digital advertising has accelerated.

One way the industry has tried to diversify its consumer outreach has been to add unique amenities at its locations to attract loyal customers. This product segment includes revenue from spa services and treatments at gyms and fitness centers.
Some additional services offered by the industry include, but aren’t limited to: ice and roller rinks, childcare services and admission to live sporting events.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Participation in sports measures the percentage of individuals participating in sports, recreation or exercise daily. Athletes and enthusiasts often seek specialized gyms to enhance their performance or recovery, leading to higher memberships and utilization rates. This increased engagement helps fitness centers expand their services and facilities as they cater to a growing base of motivated and active clients.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast is home to one of the largest population segments in the US. The region's rising population, driven by economic opportunities and a lower cost of living, has led to a higher concentration of gyms and fitness clubs.
The region's favorable weather is a crucial element for franchise success in the area. Warm temperatures year-round create an ideal climate for gyms and fitness centers to operate successfully.

The Mid-Atlantic's dense population makes it an ideal location for these establishments. Consumers prefer to have fitness centers close to home, contributing to the density of gym, health and fitness centers in this area.

Despite its less favorable climate, the Great Lakes region boasts many gyms and fitness centers. This presence is bolstered by large population hubs in states like Illinois, which support a strong demand for such facilities.
The Southwest benefits from its warm climate, making it an ideal environment for gyms and fitness centers to thrive. The favorable weather supports year-round outdoor activities and fitness routines.
Some regions of the US, like the Plains, have a notably lower concentration of gym, health and fitness centers.
New England's consistently cold weather and poor climate conditions also contribute to a reduced number of gyms and health clubs.
The Rocky Mountains' challenging geography discourages expansion in that area.

regulations_points.regulation_title: Consumer Protection and Contractual Regulatory Guidelines
regulations_points.regulation_description: State and provincial statutes and regulations across the United States impact gym, health and fitness clubs by stipulating certain forms and governing membership contract terms. These rules typically provide members the right to cancel contracts and often mandate an escrow for funds from pre-opening sales or require a bond or proof of financial responsibility, ensuring consumer protection and financial stability within the industry.

Gym, health and fitness clubs must adhere to a range of federal, state and provincial regulations related to membership sales, financing and debt collection. Key laws include the Truth-in-Lending Act and Regulation Z, along with state and provincial debt-collection laws. These regulations can be interpreted differently by various state and federal enforcement agencies, impacting how clubs operate financially and handle memberships.

Federal regulations impact advertising in the health and fitness industry, particularly for nutritional products. The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) oversees the formulation, manufacture and labeling of vitamins and supplements. Meanwhile, the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) handles marketing and advertising claims. Adherence to these guidelines is crucial for health clubs to ensure compliance and avoid penalties, enhancing consumer trust and credibility.

concentration_points.concentration_description: A HIGH LEVEL OF FRAGMENTATION WITHIN THE INDUSTRY LIMITS EXPANSION POTENTIAL FOR NEW ENTRANTS
DEPENDENCE ON EXTERNAL FACTORS PLAYS A ROLE IN DIFFICULTY OF MAINTAINING CONSISTENT GROWTH

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Deterioration of equipment contributes to substantial depreciation costs for gym, health and fitness clubs
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Since gym equipment deteriorates in quality over time, the necessity for upgrades to the machines and constant maintenance to slow down depreciation creates sizable costs for the industry.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Administrative Costs and Insurance Prove Pricey for Gym, Health and Fitness Clubs
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Administrative costs include expenses like maintaining and updating gym equipment, payroll for staff, utilities, marketing, janitorial services and other overhead costs, all of which could significantly impact the profitability of a gym, health or fitness center. Insurance not only provides protection for potential accidents or injuries at the gym but also serves as a safety net for unforeseen damages or lawsuits, solidifying its role as a critical aspect of gym operations.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Quality Service Requires Quality Employees, Hiking Wage Costs
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: The largest expenditure for gyms and fitness centers remains wages, as the cost of labor continues to match capital costs for successful fitness centers. Since the facilities require constant maintenance and excellent customer service, employees are in high demand and require notable compensation to meet those requirements.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Memberships Remain a Key Point of Emphasis for Profitability
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: One of the biggest factors in the success of industry growth has been memberships, both in terms of new sign-up rates and retention rates. The negative impact of COVID-19 forced many gym, health and fitness clubs to lower membership costs to avoid hemorrhaging large numbers of consumers while maintaining a favorable price for new consumers. Profit has yet to recover from this disruption.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Establishing a gym involves moderate capital costs, with notable financial investment needed to help build brand recognition and promote services. Gyms also face ongoing expenses for maintaining and updating equipment.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Consumer trends and macroeconomic factors highly influence volatility
volatility_points.volatility_description: - Gyms and fitness centers rely heavily on consistent consumer activity, making them susceptible to economic fluctuations. Any significant drop in consumer interest can contribute to instability. - Shifts toward substitutes and free alternatives hinder expansion efforts, underscoring the need for effective consumer outreach to maintain growth. - Economic downturns limit discretionary spending, which impacts the level of gym memberships and revenue.

- Since gyms and fitness centers are considered discretionary services, consumers will patronize gym, health and fitness centers when they have the fiscal capability. When access to disposable income expands, consumers can spend more on gym, health and fitness memberships. - The prevalence of free or affordable online workout classes highlights the impact of technological shifts on consumer behavior. Fitness centers must continually innovate and offer hybrid models to stay relevant in a competitive market.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Seasonal fluctuations affect gym, health and fitness club memberships
volatility_points.volatility_description: - New Year's Resolutions in January contribute to a surge in memberships as people set fitness goals, but many drop off by spring, leading to fluctuating revenue. Warmer months can cause a dip in gym attendance as people opt for outdoor activities, reducing membership renewals and class participation. The holiday season often leads to lower gym traffic as people prioritize travel and celebrations over workouts, temporarily affecting revenue streams.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: EXPANDING INTEREST IN PERSONAL TRAINERS AND PRIVATE CLASSES
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Consumer changes are shifting in favor of personal training. Attendance away from traditional densely occupied gym facilities has been diminished, with consumer preference towards private and smaller group workouts rapidly growing.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Adopting online communication technology transformed how gym, health and fitness clubs communicate with customers.
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Aspects of services like fitness classes, billing and other administrative tasks are easily managed using the most up-to-date technologies.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: HEIGHTENED EMPHASIS ON FAMILY GARNERS HIGHER APPEAL
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Many gyms and fitness clubs are now adding amenities customized for children, including tennis courts and childcare services. These adjustments aim to cater to a broader consumer base that seeks family-inclusive experiences. Membership plans incorporating child-related costs are becoming increasingly common, appealing directly to families wanting to engage in fitness activities together.

FAQs.question: As time-poor consumers finding it difficult to incorporate industry services into their routine. How well does your company market to consumers with limited leisure time?
FAQs.answer: Some fitness centers market the ease and convenience of using their facilities and personal trainers. The advancement of online classes has provided the industry with another tool to win over time-crunched consumers.

FAQs.question: A high-profile location offering easy access and parking can provide a competitive advantage for operators in this industry. Are you located in high traffic areas to increase your exposure?
FAQs.answer: Fitness centers benefit from locating in easily accessible areas, since most consumers will not travel far distances to visit the gym.

FAQs.question: Fitness operators that have a large number of establishments and provide a wide range of services are able to attract and retain new and existing members and reduce costs. Have you considered acquisitions to achieve higher operating efficiencies?
FAQs.answer: While mergers and acquisitions are not significant, they can be used as a way to achieve operating efficiencies and reduce costs.

FAQs.question: Radio frequency identification (RFID) is becoming a key technology for service providers. Does your company use identification technology to increase consumer access, enhance value and reduce wait times?
FAQs.answer: Many gyms have incorporated technology into the equipment used their facilities and developed mobile applications that help further involve consumers in the world of physical fitness.

FAQs.question: Wages are the largest cost for the industry, has your company explored lowering wage costs through part-time labor and automation via point-of-sale systems?
FAQs.answer: Some gyms and fitness centers have prioritized part-time workers as part of an effort to reduce wage costs, which make up a significant chunk of total revenue for the industry. While some aspects of labor cannot be replaced by automation like personal trainers, others can be done by using new technology, such as check-in scanners.

FAQs.question: State and provincial statutes and regulations prescribe certain forms and regulate the terms and provisions of membership contracts, including giving members the right to cancel the contract. Do you offer membership agreements, tickets or passes that may be subject to state or federal regulation?
FAQs.answer: Different states have different regulations involving membership cancellations and "cool-down" periods.

FAQs.question: Are you up-to-date with legislative and regulatory changes that may allow your company to expand into new markets?
FAQs.answer: Large industry operators have in-house compliance teams that assist with expansion, while smaller players rely on significant time and research investments.

FAQs.question: Member retention is a key component in fitness centers' profitability, as many gym, health and fitness centers have fixed overhead costs. Do you have a high retention rate among consumers under contract?
FAQs.answer: Retention rates are important since it is much more lucrative to maintain a client than attract a new one. As a result, gyms are increasingly focusing on new retention efforts. If retention rates are low, the company could consider lowering membership costs or fixing structural problems at their facilities like broken machines.

FAQs.question: Does your company have to purchase new equipment on an annual basis?
FAQs.answer: Some gym equipment has a long lifespan and is replaced infrequently, while others are replaced annually or semiannually. Expenditure on capital includes purchasing new and replacing old equipment, like treadmills and weight machines. To operate efficiently and profitably, enterprises must continually acquire up-to-date fitness technology to maintain and attract their customer base.

FAQs.question: How do you advertise your services? Have you ever used any promotional offers to attract customers?
FAQs.answer: Being able to promote a business effectively increases awareness and attracts greater membership and local patronage. A business could advertise a discounted gym membership or could offer financial incentives if a consumer brings a guest with them to their facility, which provides excellent advertising and broadens the outreach by the company.

FAQs.question: With coronavirus fears, are you located in a densely populated area that is subject to a high infection rate?
FAQs.answer: Easy access for clients. A high-profile location offering easy access and parking can provide a competitive advantage for operators in this industry. If there is a decline in foot traffic, a company could bolster their online classes offerings to consumers.

FAQs.question: How do ensure that you have the best possible equipment for your gym? How do you maintain the upkeep on said equipment? Which safety measures were put in place to reduce coronavirus transmission?
FAQs.answer: Providing appropriate equipment and maintaining it regularly is essential to attracting and retaining customers. One of the most important long-term costs for the industry is maintenance costs, particularly as there are no new technological inventions within the gym equipment sphere. If a facility's equipment is properly maintained and cleaned, then it will create lower operational costs in the long-term while maintaining a high level of customer service.

FAQs.question: How do you cater to consumers with limited available leisure time? Are your locations convenient for time-strapped consumers?
FAQs.answer: When individuals have more leisure time, they can allocate more time toward their fitness regimen, which spurs consumer demand for gym, health and fitness club memberships. The recent growth of online classes and personalized trainers as a segment of the industry further highlights the higher emphasis placed on time by consumers, which makes convenient location a crucial aspect for the industry's success.

FAQs.question: What percentage of your clientele participate in sports?
FAQs.answer: Greater participation in sports reflects more health-conscious individuals, which typically increases consumer demand for gym, health and fitness club memberships.

FAQs.question: What offerings do you provide tailored to athletes?
FAQs.answer: Some of the facilities provided at gyms and fitness centers are tailored to athletes like recovery rooms, cryotherapy sessions, and saunas.

FAQs.question: How do you respond to varying trends in consumer spending? How are memberships priced in response to reduced demand?
FAQs.answer: As consumer spending rises, more individuals can purchase gym, health and fitness club memberships. As consumer spending increases, more consumers are willing to spend high-cost, all-inclusive gym memberships. If there is reduced demand from consumers, one option is to create a discounted membership plan that is cheaper over a longer period of time. This can incentivize previously disinterested consumers and provide a good marketing tool to accelerate brand recognition towards new potential consumers.
